column16: Location likely not Santa Rita Corozal, rather Ichpaatun–Oxtancah–San Manuel [archaeological] complex [opp Tamalcab Isl, sev km N of Calderitas, Q. Roo, Mexico] /v Jones 280–281 /// Location = 3 [Sp naut] leagues N or S of mouth of Hondo ie site of an estancia of a Bacalar vecino in 1618 [= date of Fr Bartolomé Fuensalida + Alcalde ordinario of Bacalar journey via Bacalar–Hondo R–New R–Old R–Macal R to Tipu] /v Jones 281–282 /Cogolludo lib 9 cap 6 /// Location possibly or likely = Santa Rita Corozal, eg Diane Z. Chase, *Archaeology* 34(sn), "The Maya Postclassic at Santa Rita Corozal" [1981], 25–33 / Grant D. Jones, *Belcast Journal of Belizean Affairs* 1(1), "Maya-Spanish Relations in Sixteenth Century Belize" [1984], 30-31 /v Jones 282 / Ueli Hostettler & Matthew Restall, *Maya Survivalism* [Markt Schwaben, Verlag Anton Saurwein, 2001], 37–50 /v Graham 130
Possibly see mention of "chinamitas" near Tipu in Avendaño 1695–1696 Hon map in New Lib Ayer MS 1040 = Aliphat 863 /v Aliphat 864

column5: Lamanay / Laimaná / Lamayna / La Manai / Indian Church
column16: xxx Indian Church village relocated after discovery of Lamanai archaeological site /v Graham 224 /// 1641 Mayan residents relocate, possibly under Itza pressure /v Jones C xxx /v Graham 236 /// See Tracie Diane Mayfield, MA Thesis for Illinois State U, 2009,  "Ceramics, Landscape, and Colonialism: Archaeological analysis of the British Settlement at Lamanai, Belize, 1837 to 1868" / Darcy L. Wiewall, PhD Thesis U of California in Riverside Calif., 2009, "Identifying the Impact of the Spanish Colonial Regime on Maya Household Production at Lamanai, Belize, during the Terminal Postclassic to Early Colonial Transition" /v Graham 254
